awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Single Crystal X-Ray Diffractometer for Structure Determination and Diffuse Scattering on Small Molecules, Macromolecules, and Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Elizabeth Papish from University of Alabama Tuscaloosa and colleagues Kevin Shaughnessy, Paul Rupar, Jack Dunkle and Jared Allred have acquired a dual source single crystal diffractometer equipped with a high resolution detector. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of graduate and undergraduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution. Students are involved in chemical and protein research. The resource is also utilized by several neighboring primarily undergraduate institutions and historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs). 

The award of the diffractometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the characterization of solid materials and new polymers to harness solar energy and studies of diffuse X-ray scattering to determine how local changes in structure lead to macroscopic properties. The instrumentation is also used for studies following the syntheses of monodisperse small nanomolecules and the design of catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction and cross-coupling. The diffractometer benefits studies of biological macromolecules to understand gene expression and antibiotic resistance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The crystal structures solved for the Papish and Shaughnessy groups helped determine how catalysts worked and helped us determine how tomake better catalysts. The structures solved for the Papish group also helped us determine whether photodissociation or singlet oxygen formation would dominate and this in turn allowed us to predict toxicity of compounds towards cancer cells. The Allred group has used the instrument to detect diffuse scattering in crystals and this has allowed them to develop new methods for merging the results from user facilities with synchrotron data. Allred's work is aimed at understanding what determines the metal to insulator transition in various materials, and how that relates to structure. His work touches on the fields of physics and magnetism. The Dunkle group is working with the Frantom and Vincent groups to obtain data to better understand how chromium is damaging to DNA. For the Suf project studying how desulfurase enzymes work, the obtained structures, in conjunction with biochemical assays, confirm the critical role of each of these residues in catalysis and give clues as to the mechanistic role of each residue. Broader Impacts: 11 undergraduate students (7 women) have benefitted from either generation of samples for XRD analysis or from coauthorship of papers in which single crystal XRD was a key component of their published paper. 35 graduate students (including 17 women, 5 underrepresented minorities, and 2 LBGTQ+ individuals) have used the SC XRD in their research. Direct access to the instrument has been critical for their professional development. 5 postdoctoral fellows (including 1 woman) have used the instrument. Many undergraduate (including REU students), graduate student, and postdocs have used the instrument or gotten tours of the facility. At least 55-70 students have used the instrument in their courses. This instrument has improved their education. Both of the above students using the facility (for courses and research) have included several students that are underrepresented in science (african american, latinx, and women). 13 papers have been published, 6 papers are in preparation or submitted, 94 presentation have been given by students and professors who use the instrument, and nearly 500 samples have been analyzed. 

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2021
Modified by: Elizabeth T Papish
